body:
You need to start somewhere, so it is best to start small, test the market, then grow your digital marketing strategy.


Lets look at:

  • The different types of marketing types and channels  
  • What 'doing' digital marketing looks like 
  • How to set marketing goals and stay focused on them
title: Set your digital marketing goals

body: Rob Fitzpatrick at FounderCentric explains the main types of marketing and marketing channels.
title: Marketing and marketing channels

_media._source: C6M1 : Digital Marketing Types - Contexts in which you reach customers from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: Here are a quick recap of the different types of marketing.

_items.title: Type 1: Inbound
_items.body:
These customers are coming to you. 


They have found your business because they were actively searching for the solution your product offers.


For example, if someone finds your blog through Google, that's inbound, because they were searching for something and came to you.

_items.title: Type 2: Interrupt
_items.body:
This is almost the exact opposite to inbound marketing. 


The customer is doing something else (like watching YouTube or browsing a website) and you find a way (usually through paid advertising) to interrupt what they were doing and show them your message instead.


For example, if you pay for a pop-up ad on a website, that's an interruption to the viewers of that website. 


They may decide they want what you're selling once they see the ad, but they weren't looking for it in the first place.

The customer has decided they trust you and value hearing from you, and have therefore given you permission to contact them again, usually by joining your mailing list.


For example, if you send an email or an update to your subscribers or your Facebook followers, then that's using the permission that they have already given you to get in front of them.
_items.title: Type 3: Permission

_items.body:
You spend money to get your message in front of more people.


For example, Google Adwords or Facebook Ads.
_items.title: Channel 1: Paid

_items.body: You've spent the time to build up a website, newsletter, or social network following, and now have on-going access to the people in those groups.
_items.title: Channel 2: Owed

_items.body:
Because you did such an amazing job, some of your happy customers or followers are going to tell all their friends about you. 


You can earn these recommendations by being great, but you couldn't buy it or fake it!
_items.title: Channel 3: Earned

title: Recap: Types of marketing

body:
Reality is messy sometimes.


You will have noticed that these categories overlap a little. That's okay.  


To make it clearer, other examples may help.

_items.body:
The first people you reach are your subscribers. 


That’s permission marketing.


The customer said, by virtue of the method and rules of social media, that every time you publish a video, they want to know about it. 


That permission comes through an owned channel (your YouTube channel).
_items.title: Imagine you’re publishing a YouTube video to your YouTube channel
Some of your subscribers love your video and so they share it on Facebook.
_items.body: You’ve earned that good will!

_items.title: The people who watch the video on Facebook are likely to be searching for something to entertain them or educate them
_items.body: They are coming to us, so that’s inbound marketing.

For example, in this case it could be through ads on YouTube. 


When someone watches a similar video, your video will pop up as a suggestion, interrupting the video they’re watching to put your content in front of them.
_items.title: Once that source of viewers wears out you may decide to run paid advertising to put the video in front of more people
This is an example of how one piece of media can play the role of many different kinds of advertising
_items.body:
In this case a video has reached lots of customers in different contexts and on different channels.


As you get better and more comfortable with digital marketing, you are going to learn how to combine these contexts and channels, choosing the types of marketing which will get you the most from your marketing campaigns.

title: Digital marketing in practice

body:
With so many different options to reach your customers online, how do you choose what to do and where to focus? 


Devin Hunt gives us some of his insights into this issue.
_source: C6M1 - Setting Marketing Goals from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
title: Set your marketing goals

body:
Follow this process to make sure the time you spend on marketing really matters. 


Don't just spend your whole budget on your first idea. 


Good digital marketing is about exploration and experimentation.
displayTitle: Recap: Four steps to setting marketing goals

_items.title: Decide what your marketing is trying to achieve, like increasing revenue, generating leads, or creating newsletter sign-ups.
Brainstorm lots of options of possible marketing ideas
Test them and measure the results
Throw away the ineffective ones and double-down on the promising tests

title: Recap: Four steps to setting marketing goals

body:
Funnels look different for each company.


Devin Hunt tells us how funnels work.
displayTitle: What is a funnel and how does it work?
title: What is a funnel and how does it work?

_media._source: video1-Rob 4 Funnels from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
If 10,000 people see our website, but only 10 people buy our product, we have an overall conversion rate of 0.1%.


From our original 10,000 viewers, getting only 10 sales may seem like a large drop, but remember- we’re never going to convert everyone.


We can use the funnel to break this overall conversion rate down and measure the conversion rate at each stage.


  • 10,000 viewers
  • 1000 (10%) of those viewers got value
  • 50 (5%) of those who got value become newsletter subscribers
  • 10 (20%) of those subscribers become customers

That's a funnel.


It's just the steps that a group of people go through between seeing your marketing and subscribing or signing up.
title: Worked example of a funnel

body: This is the visual version of the example worked out above.
title: Visual funnel example

title: T6C1Q1 Types of marketing

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


With 1/100 click through rate and 1/100 conversion rate, they would need 100,000 visits to get 10 sales.
_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


With 1/100 click through rate and 1/100 conversion rate, they would need 100,000 visits to get 10 sales.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


With 1/100 click through rate and 1/100 conversion rate, they would need 100,000 visits to get 10 sales.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


With 1/100 click through rate and 1/100 conversion rate, they would need 100,000 visits to get 10 sales.

_items.text:
Let's say 1 percent of the people who see your ads will click on them. And once people are on your site, 1 percent of them will become customers. 

How many people do you need to show your ad to in order to get 10 customers?

Calculation:
Visits needed = Number of sales needed x (100/click through rate) x (100/conversion rate)

title: T6C1Q2 Setting goals

body:
Jackie wants to find customers for her new product. 


She wants to spend £10,000 on a Google ads campaign.


Is this a good idea?

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


Start small and build on what works.
_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Start small and build on what works.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Start small and build on what works.

_items.text: It's good, because £10,000 is enough to get a good amount of traffic and sales
It's good, because Google ads are measurable and cost effective
It's bad, because she's spending her whole budget without testing what works first
It's bad, because there are better tools than Google ads

title: T6C1Q3 Approaches to marketing

body:
There are lots of marketing channels you could use online.


They can be categorised by context (inbound, permission, interruption) or type (paid, owned, earned).


Funnels are a way of mapping customers' journey as their commitment to you grows. They are particularly useful to spot patterns where things might be going wrong! 


Digital marketing should be approached with a test and learn philosophy. Try small campaigns, learn what you can and build on what works.
title: Set your digital marketing goals.  Let's wrap it up

body:
Let's take a deep dive into search engine optimisation (SEO), and how to get your website to show at the top of Google's search results for relevant keywords and phrases. 


Let's look at:

  • What is SEO?
  • What is involved in 'doing' SEO
  • How SEO fits into your wider marketing strategy
title: Text Title

body:
SEO stands for search engine optimisation.


When customers are entering search requests with Google, Google Ad Words matches their keywords and phrases with your websites keywords and phrases , and places your website at nearest to the top of the customers results list (organic Google results).


Being at the top of the search results really matters because:

  • 18% of people click on the first search result
  • 10% click on the second
  • 7% click on the third
  • 3% click on the fourth


And barely anyone clicks on the fifth and below.
title: What is SEO?

body:
It is important to look at how qualified your traffic is, not But just the raw number of visitors to your site.


That is, how likely is it that customers will actually buy your product?


For example, if someone searches 'where to buy an iPhone 6 in London', they're much more qualified than someone who is just searching for 'smartphone'.


SEO is about working out what questions customers are asking at different steps of their buying journey.


It is all about making sure your website appears at the right place, at the right time, and with the right information to take them to the next step.
title: Which customers does SEO reach?

body: Rob Fitzpatrick talks us through how SEO works in more detail.
_source: C6M2 - What is SEO from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
title: How does SEO work?

body:
The 'big' search terms - or head terms - can be mighty attractive. 


After all, your novelty mug business would surely love to be ranked number 1 for the customer search term 'mugs'. 


But in addition to being less qualified, these popular search terms are much harder to win because so many other websites are relevant for such a vague search term like 'mugs'. 


In other words, there is a lot of competition in the search terms business!


And as we saw previously,  if we are not able to rank highly on a search term, then it's not so valuable to us.


So instead, we might focus on the long tail of searches. These are more specific and qualified, so we try to win at lots of little searches instead of losing at one big one.


And when you take all the little terms together, they really matter.


In fact, long tail searches account for 70% of the searches that run through Google.
displayTitle: What is the head and long tail in SEO?
title: What is the head and long tail in SEO?

body:
We've talked about why SEO is so important, but what does it actually mean to have good SEO? 


Rob Fitzpatrick takes us through SEO.
_source: C6M2 - What does ''doing SEO'' involve? from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
title: What is good SEO?

body:
There are three main streams to good working SEO.


1. Researching and deciding which search terms to compete over.


2. Fixing your site so Google knows what it's about.


3. Getting Google to trust you by building links.


Fixing your site so Google knows what it's about is how Google knows that your site is relevant to the search term. 


The most important thing is to get your keywords into just a few places:

  • The page title
  • The website address or URL
  • The big header text
  • In the body text (just two or three times)

There's lots more detail you can get into if you want to, but if you get these bits right, you're well on your way. People like to make it sound complicated, but it's really pretty straightforward.
title: Three SEO streams

body: Google keyword planner tool will help to make sense of it all.
_source: C6M2 - Keyword Research / Planning from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
title: Deep dive: Keyword research

body:
Back links are the links that other pages on the internet make to your page.


Google bases its trust in your website on the number of other links to your site and who they are from. Trusted sites (like big brands and universities) provide more 'link juice' and elevates Google's trust in your site even more, which in turn bumps you up the search results list.


There are two ways to get links.

  • Reach out to relevant people directly and convince them to link to you
  • Create a great website with helpful content that other people want to link to and show off to their own audience

Both of these take time, but that's OK!


Rob Fitzpatrick takes through back links.
title: Deep dive: Building back links

_media._source: video1-Rob 9 SEO basics - creating trust and backlinks from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
Sometimes people will offer to 'sell' you links for about $50 each as a quick fix for your link building strategy. 


You should always say 'no' to this offer.


Schemes like these can work for a little while, but they are expensive and Google always figures it out. Once they do, they can punish you by blacklisting your site, which completely removes it from Google results. 


All these sneaky tactics are called blackhat SEO, and you should avoid them. The quick boost isn't worth the risk of your whole site being blacklisted.
title: Link building no-nos

That is, those who are most likely to buy a holiday?

title: T6C2Q3 Keyword research

body:
SEO is just a set of simple rules on searching and keywords to follow over the long-term. 


At the same time, keep an eye on your analytics and you'll start to see which search terms bring the best traffic.


This allows you to spend more time on the promising search terms and ignore the less effective ones.


Create great content that people want to link to, and then just keep doing it!
title: How can I get my site to the top of Google search results? Let's wrap it up

body:
Content is the bread and butter of any marketing activity. 


Let's have a look at:

  • What content marketing is and how it works
  • How to brainstorm ideas for content that will be effective for your marketing strategy
  • Which platforms you could share your content on
title: The stuff people want and need!

body:
Content is anything you publish that will help and engage with your customers. This could be articles, videos, photos, interviews, or anything else of value.


Broadly speaking, your whole marketing strategy will involve making this content, publishing it on your website and posting links to it on platforms such as Facebook, LinkedIn and Twitter.


You will make sales by:

  • bringing customers back to your website  
  • building relationships with customers so that they grow to like and trust you

So what content should you make? Rule number 1 is to make content that makes viewers happy (not that it is the primary reason your product sells!)


Surprised? 


In fact, 80% of your content marketing should have nothing to do with your product. Only 20% of it should mention what you're selling.
title: What is content marketing?

body:
As we mentioned before, content-led marketing involves making content, publishing it on your website and promoting it on multiple platforms. 


A great place to publish content on your website is through your blog. 


Here are some benefits of a blog full of engaging content.
displayTitle: Get the most out of blogging

_items.body:
Each new blog post you create is a new web page, which means it can catch a long-tail search result! 


Over time, this could build up to a large amount of long tail traffic.


Any images and videos you use can also be tagged to draw in image and Youtube searchers, too.
_items.title: Capture SEO traffic
Attract blog followers
_items.body:
Your blog can also attract a following of readers who subscribe via RSS feed. 


This is likely to be a much smaller number of visitors than SEO.

title: Get the most out of blogging

body: Rob Fitzpatrick goes into more detail about using your blog, especially to attract SEO customers.
displayTitle: Use your blog to attract SEO
title: Use your blog to attract SEO

_media._source: C6M3 - Blogging from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
YouTube is the world’s second largest search engine. It has more searches than Bing. It’s also far easier to show up at the top of YouTube results than at the top of Google results.


You can use video in the same way as blog posts - to inform, inspire, and entertain your customers. If you put it on YouTube, people will find it and can subscribe if they think your content is valuable to them.


So if you sell television equipment, you could create a series of videos on how to fix common television problems. It doesn't need to be perfect. Focus on your customers and don't get lost in the details.


Be sure to include metadata like the video description and tags as this metadata will help your video to show up in search results.


YouTube also provides incredible analytics so you can refine your videos as you go. For example, seeing at what point people stop watching a video. At that moment, they either have what they want, or they are bored - and that could be for multiple reasons.


Rob provides us with more of his insights.
title: Text Title

_media._source: C6M3 - Video from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
Here are just a few ideas for content and platforms. There are loads more and new ones are being created and getting popular every day. Keep an eye open for new technologies and be ready to try something new.


Again, it comes back to an obsession with your customers.

Go to where they are and make them happy!


That's what content marketing is all about. And then the traffic, trust, and customer loyalty will all flow back to you!
displayTitle: Where can you share your content?

_items.title: Thought leadership - LinkedIn
_items.body: A management consultancy interviewing a CEO or CIO about a topical industry challenge and posting the interview on LinkedIn.

_items.title: Craft video on Etsy
_items.body: A crochet bikini maker creating a video with a crochet trick and posting it on YouTube and Etsy.

_items.title: Presentation slides on Slideshare
_items.body: An HR consultancy sharing a slideshow from a recent event on '10 ways to spread the love in the office'.

_items.title: Living room decoration ideas on Pinterest
_items.body: An affordable art website creating a 'living room inspiration, Spring 2017' mood board.
A handbag brand sharing London street-style photos of people wearing outfits with handbags.
_items.title: Fashion inspiration on Instagram

_items.body: An online parenting magazine posting articles about dealing with tantrums.
_items.title: Answering questions on Quora
Industry insights on Medium
_items.body: The founder of a startup that makes robots shares his experiences around the moral dilemmas that he faces in his work.

title: Where can you share your content?

title: T6C3Q2 Sharing content

body:
Consider the following.


You need to plan a blog post to attract traffic to a children's toy site. 


Which of the following posts would deliver most value to your visitors?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure that's right? 


Being overly promotional will only appeal to customers who are in the final stages of their buying journey and could be a turn-off for customers who are still considering buying.
_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure that's right?


Being overly promotional will only appeal to customers who are in the final stages of their buying journey and could be a turn-off for customers who are still considering buying.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure that's right?


Being overly promotional will only appeal to customers who are in the final stages of their buying journey and could be a turn-off for customers who are still considering buying.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!  


Being overly promotional will only appeal to customers who are in the final stages of their buying journey and could be a turn-off for customers who are still considering buying.

_items.text: Fun activities to do with your kids this holiday break
10 reasons why our new toys are great
Announcement: We have new management and are now hiring
Sale! Buy in the next 48 hours and get a 20% discount!

title: T6C3Q3 Engaging content

body:
Content that informs, engages or entertains your customers should be the bread and butter of your marketing strategy. 


Blogging, video content, slidedecks, and interviews are examples of content that can bring customers to your site and make them feel positively towards you. It doesn't need to be perfect - just clear and user focused. 


As well as attracting and building good relationships with your customers, content can attract back links from other bloggers or websites. They can appear in the search results themselves, which will help you with your SEO. 


And always add your target keywords and tags wherever you can. Make the most of a video description field and the opportunity to add keywords with an article.
title: Choose what content to make. Let's wrap it up

body:
Newsletters are a great (and inexpensive) way to reach specific sub-segments of customers with targeted messages.


Let's have a look at:

  • Brainstorming great ideas for newsletter content 
  • Deciding which type of newsletter to have (classic vs auto-responders)
  • Choosing tools to measure and analyse data from your newsletter campaigns
title: Text Title

body:
Permission marketing is based on the idea that people don't buy from strangers. Instead, they buy from people and companies they trust.


The idea is to focus on building an audience or tribe of people who care about the same stuff you do, and then keep in touch with them and keep over-delivering value.


Our main goal when someone reaches your website is NOT to convince them to buy, but rather to get permission to contact them again. That permission gives you trust, a relationship, and access to their inbox.
title: Permission-based marketing

body:
Emails may seem simple and mundane, but if you get it right, they can really work for you.


But will only only work if you deliver great value content. If you write a boring newsletter or email that only plugs your product, there will be limited value for the audience there.


Do you recall what content marketing is all about? That's right, creating value for your audience and not promoting yourself.


Well, if you’ve consistently over-delivered on value and maintained an ongoing relationship, you’re already in the customer’s mind when they do come to purchase.


Rob Fitzpatrick gives us some more insights into permission marketing  and newsletters.
title: How newsletters can help

_media._source: C6M4 - Permission marketing Intro from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

displayTitle: What separates a great newsletter from boring spam?

_items.body: If you are in a fast-moving industry, give your audience breaking news that matters right now.
_items.title: News and trends

_items.body: Teach and inform people with tutorials, guidance and helpful pointers.
_items.title: Education and tips

_items.body:
Find the best stuff on the web (created by other people) and link to it. 


Since you are the expert, you are going to be able to point them in the direction of the best stuff to spend time on, which is always appreciated.
_items.title: Curation and links
Inspiration and motivation
_items.body: Provide ongoing encouragement to your audience to accomplish something difficult they might be doing, like writing a book or sticking to a fitness plan.

title: What separates a great newsletter from boring spam?

body:
There are essentially two types of newsletter. 

Choose the one that works best for you.
displayTitle: What type of newsletter should I use?

_items.backText:
Classic newsletters are what we normally think of when we talk about email marketing. 
Each month you send out the same email to all of your current subscribers.
If someone new joins, they get the next email, but never see the previous ones.
This type of newsletter is great for news and current events.

Auto-responders are slightly different. 
As soon as someone subscribes, they get the first email in an ongoing series, and each week or month they'll receive the next one.
If someone new joins, that person also starts from the beginning. So everyone receives every email, but not necessarily at the same time. 
This type of newsletter is great for an educational course.

title: What type of newsletter should I use?

body:
There are a host of tools to help you find out what is working and what is not in your newsletter campaigns. 


These metrics can tell you who is opening them, are they engaging with the content, are they going on to buy? 


Rob Fitzpatrick tells us about some of his favourite tools.
displayTitle: Measure the success of your newsletter campaign
title: Measure the success of your newsletter campaign

_media._source: C6M4 - Newsletter tools and analytics from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: Here are some common questions entrepreneurs face when they set up newsletter campaigns.

_items.body:
Most businesses send their newsletters either weekly or monthly, depending on what sort of content they're sharing and what their customers enjoy. 


There is no best practice for this, but try to remember to be regular (for example, stick to a predictable posting schedule), and to keep improving it until people love to read it.
_items.title: How often should I send my newsletter?

_items.body:
Initial conversion rates from viewers to subscribers are low- normally 1 to 5% on average. 


But once they have subscribed, they tend to stick around!
_items.title: What proportion of people will read it?

_items.body:
One way to try to encourage subscriptions is to offer a free gift.


This could include your book, or a video tutorial, anything that adds even more value.


This should incentivise them to give you permission to contact them.
_items.title: What are some good content ideas?

_items.text: Which products or content customers are most interested in.
What type of content customers like to consume
Whether different customer groups have different interests
How much money customers usually spend online

title: T6C4Q3 Measuring analytics

body:
Good newsletter content follows the same rules as any marketing content - focus on helping your customer rather than just plugging yourself. 


Before starting your newsletter strategy, you need to decide how often to send the newsletter, which type of newsletter you will send, and how you will measure its performance. 


Newsletters can gather golden insights for you about what customers are really interested in. For example, female shoppers in Wimbledon love the extra mature cheddar from Chertsey. 


These insights can inform your wider marketing activities, from decisions about what content to put on your homepage or how to phrase the headlines of your blogs.
title: Newsletters as a marketing tool. Let's wrap it up

body:
Do you know what paid advertising is, how it works and what it might cost?


Let's find out:

  • How much your digital advertising might cost 
  • How paid advertising works on Facebook and Google
  • How re-targeting works
title: Paid advertising

_source: C6M5 - Rob 18 Advertising buzzwords and how much online ads cost from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
displayTitle: How much do digital ads cost?
body:
It is impossible to calculate the exact cost of a digital marketing campaign upfront, since many advertising platforms work on a pay-as-you-go basis where you are only charged when people click on your ads. 


Rob Fitzpatrick provides us with some of his insights into paid advertising.
title: How much do digital ads cost?

body: Here is a recap of Robs insights and some buzzwords used to calculate the cost of digital advertising.

_items.body: CPM - Cost per mil (thousand) views of your ad
_items.title: CPM
CPE
_items.body: CPE - Cost per person who engages with the ads
CPC - Cost per click on your ad, which means per visitor to your website
_items.title: CPC
CPA
_items.body: CPA - Cost per action on your site, such as someone buying your product

title: Marketing costs explained

body:
Now that we are clear on the buzzwords, how can we work out how much you are paying to get each new customer to your website?  


Rob does the math!
displayTitle: How much are you paying for each customer?
title: How much are you paying for each customer?

_media._source: C6M5 - Advertising math - converting from CPM to CPC from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
Two of the most popular and powerful advertising platforms are Facebook and Google. 


Rob provides his insights into the cost effectiveness of these popular web services.
title: Advertising on Facebook and Google

_media._source: video1-Rob 22 Advertising on Facebook and Google from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
Both Google and Facebook are great to test with. 


Even £20 can get you enough clicks so that you can gather some really useful data.
displayTitle: Recap: Advertising on Google and Facebook

_items.backText:
Google ads are priced as cost per click. 
The more people who want to advertise for a certain term, the higher the cost per click.
One of the tricks is to find search terms that have lower competition, but still convert to sales.

Facebook ads can be priced as cost per engagement, cost per click, cost per mil, and a variety of other ways depending on the type of campaign you want to run. 
Facebook is also great for specific targeting. You can target people by their location, which pages they like, their gender, age, relationship status, the list goes on and on.

title: Flip Card Title

body:
Re-targeting allows you to show your ads only to people who have already been on your site or looked at your products. 


That means that they are already tempted, and you can just pay to tip them over the edge.


This works best for e-commerce companies with a product to sell online, as opposed to brand advertisers like Coca-Cola who just want to make you feel good about the brand, but aren't actually expecting you to buy a coke right away.


Rob provides us with his insights into re-targeting.
_source: video1-Rob 23 Understanding retargeting for ecommerce ads from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
displayTitle: Re-targeting: What is it and how does it work?
title: Re-targeting: What is it and how does it work?

body: Collect 50 points for every correct answer
title: Text Title

body:
If you're paying £10 per mille and have a 1% click through rate, what is your cost per click (in £)?


Calculation:

Your cost per click = cost per mille / (1000 x click through rate)

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure?


Your cost per click = cost per mille / (1000*click through rate)
_incorrect.final:
Are you sure? 


Your cost per click = cost per mille / (1000*click through rate)

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Your cost per click = cost per mille / (1000*click through rate)

Sharing complex marketing insights

title: T6C5Q3 Re-targeting

body:
Your cost per click is how much it costs you to get a new customer. This is known as CPC. 


Your cost per mille is how much you pay for 1000 people to see your ad. This is known as CPM. 


Your conversion rate is the % of people who click on your ad. This is known as CTR.


Costs are usually measured using this formula.

Your cost per click = cost per mille / (1000 x click through rate %)


Re-targeting, Facebook ads and Adwords are other strong ways to get your high quality content to your customers.
title: Mastering paid advertising. Let's wrap it up

body:
Viral marketing is a great method of marketing that is largely conducted via your customers.


Let's see how to:

  • Create referrals and evangelists around a great product
  • Measure how likely content is to go viral 
  • Start small with your digital marketing
title: A great product sells itself.

body:
Even if you have the world's greatest marketing campaign, it's not going to help if your website is poor.


A poor website could be boring, have inaccurate content, be dated, have badly written copy, and so on. 


If your product is not good, people may buy it (thanks to the great sales job you did), but then the bad reviews and complaints and returns will start piling up and the business fails.


Sound a bit gloomy? Don't worry, if we get a better understanding of this, we can turn it around to our benefit!
displayTitle: What is great marketing all about?
title: What is great marketing all about?

_source: video1-Rob 24 Great marketing doesn't stop at the ad from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
body: Rob Fitzpatrick explains how great products sell themselves.
title: How great products sell themselves

body:
If your product is good enough, you get free and deeply persuasive marketing, both online and offline, through your customers telling their friends about you and your product. 


Customers do this by leaving reviews on Amazon, making YouTube videos about using your product, or talking about it at a party, for example.  


To be a world class marketer, you should have your eye on the entire experience!
title: Creating referrals and evangelists

body: Rob Fitzpatrick shares some tips on how to nurture a community of evangelists.
title: Nurture your community of evangelists

_media._source: video2-Rob 25 Creating referrals and evangelists with a great product from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
We always hope that our marketing will go viral and that the whole world will see it at no cost. But, can that ever really happen? 


Even the best viral marketers in the world are still crossing their fingers. It's super risky and it often doesn't work. You can't really plan that campaign because you never know what's going to catch the world's interest. You have to use your skills but you also need to have a bit of luck!


However, if you keep a close eye on which pieces of your content are getting a good response, you can invest in pushing it out as far as possible and running more similar campaigns. 


You can't plan a viral campaign, but you can often see when one is about to happen and make the most of it.
title: The truth about viral marketing

body:
We've covered all the big moving pieces in digital marketing. 


It's very much a craft, not a science. You learn it by trying stuff out. 


Start with a small project, take it seriously, and see how far you can grow it.

_items.title: Grow a blog
_items.body:
You can put a content marketing to work yourself. 


Choose an audience, figure out what they like to read, create content they value, find a way to reach them, and then convert them into subscribers. 


Blogging gives you experience with the whole content marketing funnel. Plus, as a bonus, you get an owned audience (your subscribers) who have given you permission to stay in touch. Perfect!

_items.title: Grow a Facebook page
_items.body:
Another way to practise your content marketing is to grow a Facebook page or group. 


Again, find an excited group of people and create great content that makes them want to subscribe. This also gives you some experience with customer support and answering people's questions. 


Plus, you can even try spending a tiny bit of money on Facebook ads to see how they work for growing your audience.

Do you have a product or a business idea? 


Make a great video, write some killer copy, and run a Kickstarter campaign to see if you can crowdfund it.


Put all your marketing tricks to work to bring people to your page and to get them to fund your project.
_items.title: Run a Kickstarter campaign

title: Digital marketing: Where to begin

title: T6C6Q2 Viral content

body: What is the most important thing about digital marketing?

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure that's right?


Marketing is a craft not a science so start small and test early.
_incorrect.final:
Are you sure that's right? 


Marketing is a craft not a science so start small and test early.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Marketing is a craft not a science so start small and test early.

_items.text: To make sure every detail is right. Go big - as after all, it is all about reaching as many people as possible
Start small and test everything you do so you know where to spend your time, effort and money

title: T6C6Q3 Where to start

body:
Great marketing is mainly about having a great product - that will get your customers to do your marketing for you. 


Having a good looking website with high quality content is also a must in the digital world. 


Digital marketing is part art and part science. Start small and don't aim for perfection. Setting up a Facebook page and writing and promoting some blog posts is a good place to start, too.


Test everything as you go. See what customers respond to, where you are getting value for money and build on what works. Don't expect your content to go viral - it is rare and you'll be super lucky if it does.
title: Viral marketing: How can I get my customers to do my marketing for me?
